description.narrative: Objective: To expand and strengthen the terrestrial PA system in the Philippines by developing new PA models and building capacity for effective management of the system

comment.narrative:
59 terrestrial PAs covering 2.6 million hectares
New PAs are established only through the NIPAS process
No program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PAs to cover new conservation areas

Additional 9 terrestrial PAs covering 400,000 hectares, bringing the total area of KBA under protection to 3 million hectares
At least three new governance types IP, LGU and local community managed conservation areas recognized by Executive fiat as part of national PA system
Program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PA system to include new conservation areas within KBAs developed and ready for implementation

Partially Achieved. Since Project start, a total of 46 PAs/LCAs and ICCAs covering 400,724 hectares of KBAs have been added to the country’s protected area system:
3 PAs covering 174,549 hectares
26 LCAs from NewCAPP covering 80,163 hectares
10 ICCAs from NewCAPP covering 68,179 hectares; 3 ICCAs registered at UNEP/WCMC
1 LCA in BPP site (Mt. Hamiguitan) - 3,784 hectares
5 ICCAs recognized through FPE, and PTFCF covering 73,002 hectares
1 ICCA registered at UNEP/WCMC from non NewCAPP sites - 1,047 hectares
This brings to 3,007,009 hectares, the total area of KBAs under protection.
The Senate has passed on Second Reading, the Enhanced NIPAS Bill seeking to legislate 97 PAs, and strengthen NIPAS provisions, including recognition of ICCAs within PAs. Of these, 92 are existing PAs with Presidential Proclamations, while 5 are new PAs that will form part of the national PA estate. Once approved, the Bill will strengthen the legal status of these nationally legislated PAs under the NIPAS. In all, these 97 PAs cover 2,674,830.68 hectares and an additional of 179, 439.60 hectares of buffer zones in all; 59 are within KBA.
Based on various presentations and advocacies, an additional 33 LGUs and 209 IP organizations have expressed interest to establish LCAs and document their ICCAs, respectively.
GIZ-PAME is supporting LCAs and ICCAs in the establishment of 100 new sites (terrestrial and marine PAs) in KBAs.
Based on NewCAPP’s lessons and experiences, a medium sized GEF proposal has been developed to strengthen policy and capacities for ICCA recognition in the Philippines, to cover an additional 10 sites with estimated total coverage of 118,000 hectares
NewCAPP spearheaded the preparation of a National PA System Master Plan that will guide the expansion of the Philippines PA estate, based on the following criteria: (i) representativeness, comprehensiveness, and balance; (ii) adequacy; (iii) coherence and complementarity; (iv) consistency; and (v) cost effectiveness, efficiency and equity. The Plan recognizes LCAs, ICCAs and other effective area based conservation measures (OECMs) as part of the National PA System.
Only two new modalities were developed under the Project. The Project was not able to find a workable model on community-managed CA. In lieu of this, the Project tried to investigate the viability of a privately-managed CA. But this did not progress as well. But the 2 models (LCA and ICCA) proved to be very viable option in expanding the protected area system.
On the policy, while no executive fiat was secured to support LCA and ICCA, the project was able to influence Environment Management Bureau (EMB) to consider these as environmentally critical areas compelling other development activities such as mining to undertake full-blown impact assessment. The project was also able to draft a number of supportive policies and turned over to BMB. One of which was the ICCA Bill which was passed in the Committee level in both houses of Congress.
Both Congress and Senate have approved at Committee level, the Draft ICCA Bill. KBAs, LCAs and ancestral domain lands are now considered as environmentally critical areas (ECAs) per Memorandum Circular of the Environmental Management Bureau on the Revised Procedures for the Philippines EIA System.

description.narrative: Habitat range of 109 globally threatened species in 9 pilot sites protected

comment.narrative: Expected to decrease by at least 10% per year
Increase by 200%

Achieved. The habitat of 186 globally threatened in 14 project sites within 10 KBAs are now protected by the local government units, local and indigenous cultural communities through the establishments of 24 LCAs and recognition of 10 ICCAs. Below is the summary:
- 27 critically endangered (1 reptilia, 6 aves, 1 mamalia, 19 magnoliopsida)
- 34 endangered (3 amphibia, 15 aves, 4 mamalia, 11 magnoliopsida, 1 coniferopsida)
- 125 vulnerable (21 amphibia, 8 reptilia, 39 aves, 9 mamalia, 48 magnoliopsida)
- 1threatened species (1 aves Hypothymis helenae )
However, please take note that during the biodiversity assessment and resource inventory conducted in the project sites, a total of 309 species were recorded and have not been classified yet but are deemed locally important/significant. The breakdown of these species are as follow:
- 12 amphibia
- 50 reptilia
- 82 aves
- 25 mamalia
- 136 magnoliopsida
- 4 coniferopsida
These data may be taken as baseline information and partial list of species. A more comprehensive study must be undertaken especially in ICCA areas as the inventory in most sites were limited to flora. However, conduct of such study should be approved by the IP community and the design should allow them to take greater responsibility or at least encourage active participation.
In addition, there are 133 species (10 amphibia, 14 reptilia, 82 aves, 21 mamalia, 6 magnoliopsida) considered as least concern.
In Mt. Nacolod BD assessment, 2 new species of frogs were discovered, and 5 species (2 amphibia and 3 mamalia) were considered new island record.

description.narrative: Management Effectiveness in PAs and new conservation areas

comment.narrative: Average of 35 in all nine sites

Increase in METT scores in pilot sites by an average of at least 20% compared to baseline levels
METT scorecard applied in all PAs and new CAs as basis for supporting capacity development and implementing adaptive management

Achieved. Average METT Scores of NewCAPP sites increased by 31 points or 83% from the average baseline score of 37.
Overall, the increase in the METT scores can be attributed to the generation of information in the process of establishing LCA and documentation and recognition of ICCA. These information improved the planning process and identification, and provided bases for issuing local resolutions for the establishment/recognition of conservation areas. There was also improvement in the monitoring system. Also, in general, there was improvement in the condition of the important values in the CA. Lastly, the community is slowly reaping economic benefits.
At the systemic level, BMB is routinely applying METT scorecard in all PAs.

description.narrative: PA system of the Philippines has been expanded under new and diverse management regimes (ancestral domain, local government and community managed areas) to cover an additional 400,000 hectares of Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) and with enhanced potential for further expansion
Coverage of the national PA system in terms of governance types

comment.narrative: Limited to PAs established through the NIPAS process, managed by PAMBs only
Coverage of national PA system is expanded to include new conservation areas under diverse governance types (IP, LGU and local community managed areas)

Achieved. The Project has established two new modalities (LCA and ICCA) for expanding and diversifying the national protected area system. The BMB has adopted these and are being mainstreamed into the National PA System Master Plan. A Bill on ICCA was approved at the Committee level in both Houses of Congress. An Omnibus Bill that intends to legislate 97 PAs is also filed in Congress. It includes provisions on recognition of ICCA. As transitory mechanism, BMB Technical Bulletins on ICCA and LCA were prepared and undergoing final review. These specify the applicable policies to support requests for ICCA recognition and LCA establishment; and encourage field offices to provide support.
At the site level, a total of 148,342 hectares were designated as conservation areas. For ICCA, three sites (Mt. Kalatungan (http://www.iccaregistry.org/en/sites/27). Ayta Abellen tribe in Cabangan, Zambales (http://www.iccaregistry.org/en/sites/28); and Hilong hilong (http://www.iccaregistry.org/en/sites/31) have completed the entire process of documentation and are now registered at UNEP-WCMC ICCA Registry . Two additional sites - Banao tribe in BBNP Kalinga Watershed and Buhid and Bangon tribes in Mts. Iglit Baco KBA have both submitted their ICCA documentation and in the process of providing the additional information requested by UNEP-WCMC. The Balatoc tribe in Kalinga Watershed is in the final stages of the documentation and recognition process. By the end of the year, it is expected that an additional 11,000 hectares of ICCA will be included in the ICCA registry. The Dumagat Remontados in Mt. Irid Angelo KBA has yet to conduct resource inventory in the identified ICCA sites to enrich available information. Once completed, the ICCA case study will be prepared and submitted to UNEP-WCMC. However, community declaration of ICCA has been completed and its CCP and ICCA have been integrated in the ADSDPP of Dumagat Remontado, which was prepared in parallel with the ICCA documentation. For Ayta Abellen tribe in San Felipe, Zambales, the implementation was put on hold since 2014 due to internal conflicts among IP leaders within the tribe. IKSP documentation on resource management and governance, resource inventory, CCP have been completed. However, the CCP needs to be validated and the case study has to be prepared.
For LCA sites, the management plans were completed, LGU funding for initial implementation have been allocated, and all sites have secured policies to formalize the establishment of LCAs. Mangatarem and Mt. Tapulao, both in Zambales KBA, have established LCAs as critical habitats. Mangatarem has submitted their critical habitat management plans to the Office of the DENR Secretary for the issuance of Department Order. Mt. Tapulao is packaging the plan for submission also to DENR. Both LGUs have issued resolutions adopting the LCA. In Polillo Group of Islands, a total of 10,329 hectares of conservation area were strengthened/established under the Project. A draft PGI Biodiversity Conservation Strategic Action Plan was prepared in 2012 to support LCA. The three municipalities (Alcoy, Argao, and Dalaguete) covering Mts. Nug as and Lantoy KBA have agreed to establish the Nug as Palinpinon Biodiversity Corridor with a total area of 9,649 hectares. Each LGU has prepared and adopted a management plan. In Mt. Nacolod in Southern Leyte, the LCA Management Framework was adopted by the Provincial LGU through a Resolution. This Framework was turned over to the PLGU last June 29, 2015 during the environmental submit organized by the provincial government. It has 40,860 hectares within 7 municipalities in So. Leyte and Leyte. The PLGU also issued a resolution declaring Mt. Nacolod as Forest Protected Area in 2012. In Bud Bongao in Tawi Tawi, a Provincial Ordinance declaring 325 hectares of Bud Bongao Peak was issued in 2013. A Management Plan was also prepared and budget has been allocated for its implementation.

description.narrative: Extent of the national terrestrial PA system in proportion to total area of the country

comment.narrative: Achieved. 0.1 percent or 3,007,009 hectares. This represents an additional of 400,724 hectares from the baseline of 2.6 million hectares. The target was to increase the coverage of the protected area within KBAs to 3 million hectares or 10% of the total area of the country. NewCAPP contributed 148,342 hectares or 37% of the additional areas established over the course of the Project.During the Project, another PA outside of KBA was established covering 26,125 hectares - Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape-under Proclamation Number 296 signed on November 24, 2012.

description.narrative: Representation of KBAs in biogeographic zones and ecosystem types in the national PA system

comment.narrative:
Greater Luzon BZ 48%
Mindoro BZ 49%
Greater Negros Panay BZ 47%
Greater Mindanao BZ 32%
Sulu BZ 29%

Greater Luzon BZ 56%
Mindoro BZ 81%
Greater Negros Panay BZ 50%
Greater Mindanao BZ 37%
Sulu BZ 46%

Partially Achieved. At the time of design, it was thought that the Project will be able to place the entire KBA landscape under new conservation status. However, the reality is, KBAs comprise expansive landscapes which include patches of alienable and disposable lands, cultivated agriculture, forest plantations, and other land uses. Thus, the identification of new conservation areas was guided by BD assessments to determine the extent and location of areas that should be conserved; negotiations with local partners and stakeholders to engender ownership and support. As a result, the areas placed under conservation status (LCAs and ICCAs) represent only a portion (37%) of the total area of pilot KBAs of NewCAPP.
Greater Luzon BZ 53.02%. An additional 23 protected areas (15 LCAs; and 8 ICCAs) established/recognized since project start with a total of 99,939 hectares.
Mindoro BZ 58.22%. With the recognition of 3 ICCAs of the Buhid and BangonTribes in Mts. Iglit Baco KBA and 1 ICCA of the Mangyan Tagabukid, the total coverage of protected area under protection increased to 136,224 hectares against 233,590 hectares of KBA.
Greater Negros Panay BZ 49.52%. 3 LCAs comprising the Nugas Lantoy BD Corridor was established under the Project. The total area designated for conservation is 9,649 hectares bringing the total coverage to 167,929 hectares
Greater Mindanao BZ 38.52%. A total of 133,135 hectares were established from the proclamation of 2 PAs, establishment of 7LCAs, and recognition of 5 ICCA; thereby increasing the coverage to 1,023,897 hectares.
Sulu BZ 29.49%. The Project was able to establish 1 LCA in Bud Bongao; contributing 325 hectares to the 9,421 hectares baseline.

description.narrative: Program for expansion and diversification of national PA system

comment.narrative: None
Expansion and diversification of the national PA system is guided by a 5 year program

Achieved. Further expansion and diversification of the national PA system shall be guided by the Master Plan, which is an ongoing effort supported by various projects/donors. The Plan recognizes LCAs, ICCAs and OECMs as part of the national PA system.
The National Program Framework for ICCAs is contained in the Manila Declaration, which was produced from the First National ICCA Consortium in 2012.
Following the Declaration, the Project supported the establishment of the Philippine ICCA Consortium. Founded in February 2013, the Consortium adopted the name Bukluran ng mga Katutubo para sa Pangangalaga ng Kalikasan sa Pilipinas (BUKLURAN). While still in its nascent stage, it is actively participating in the discussions on ICCA at the national level:
With the BUKLURAN, the Project coordinated with the Office of Cong. Baguilat in the development of the ICCA Bill. It was passed at the Committee level of the House of Representatives in December 2014. A counterpart bill was filed by Sen. Loran Legarda in the Senate in February 2015, and was passed also at the Committee level in March 2015.
NewCAPP provided technical assistance to BMB and UNDP-Philippines in the formulation of a new project on ICCA with the BUKLURAN, UNDP, NCIP, PAFID and KASAPI. The project document was completed and submitted to GEF headquarters in May 2015.
In October 2014, the BMB-NewCAPP, in partnership with NCIP, BUKLURAN and many organizations, organized the 2nd National Conference on ICCA to assess progress of ICCA institutionalization in the country and implementation of the Manila Declaration (output of the first national conference). The Conference became a venue to share best practices and the support to ICCA was solidified. Different organizations from the government, private sector, and non-government organization committed to support the strengthening of ICCA in the country. It was also used to enhance the ADSDPP Guidelines and include the identification and documentation of ICCAs. This will usher a systemic and more systematic process. Along with BMB, the Conference was co-funded by PTFCF, GIZ, and UNDP-Philippines.
With enough lessons and experience on the ground on establishing local conservation area, the Project together with several organizations also conducted the First National Conference on LCA. Around 250 individuals from the LGUs, NGAs, NGOs, academe, private sector, and development organizations attended the conference. The Conference was able to consolidate support from all sectors on LCA and have increased buy in from DILG, HLURB and local chief executives. During the Conference, a Resolution was issued by the participants urging national government agencies to strengthen support to LGUs, and upscale the establishment of LCAs. This Resolution will be incorporated in the PA System Master Plan being developed.
Guides on the documentation and recognition of ICCA and establishment of LCA were finalized. The LCA Guide was launched with DILG and HLURB in 2015. The ICCA Sourcebook is for printing after incorporating comments from Global ICCA Consortium.

description.narrative: Incorporation of BD conservation goals in local plans

comment.narrative: Isolated efforts only by a few PAMBs and NGO partners

ADSDPP 4 (BBNP, ZMR, Mts. Iglit Baco, Mts. Irid Angelo and Binuang)
Resource management plans of local communities - 2 (Nug as Lantoy, Hilong hilong)
LGU land use and development plans 3 (Tawi tawi, Mt. Nacolod, and Polilio islands)

Achieved.
In BBNP, the ICCAs of the Banao IP community has been declared by the LGU of Balbalan as conservation areas in the updating of their CLUP.
In the case of Balatoc IP community, the CCP is being prepared following completion of the resource inventory.
In the Zambales Mountain Range: The Critical Habitat Management Plan of Mangatarem LGU has been adopted by the Council, and endorsed to DENR for confirmation. The Plan was developed to be consistent with the Forest Land Use Plan (FLUP) of the municipality.
The Critical Habitat Management Plan of Palauig LGU for Mt. Tapulao has been completed and adopted by the Council. The Plan includes the entire forest land of the municipality and therefore also represent the FLUP.
The ICCA and CCP of Aeta Abellen in Maporac, Zambales has been incorporated in the updated ADSDPP of the IP community.
The ICCA documentation of Aeta IP community in San Felipe Zambales Mountain Range has been completed, and the CCP is up for validation by the community.
In Mt. Iglit Baco PA, the CCP of the Buhid Bangon Mangyan IP community has been completed and incorporated in the updated ADSDPP. The PA Management Plan for the Iglit Baco is due for development, where the ICCA and CCP will form an integral part.
In Mt. Irid Angelo, the ICCA documentation and its CCP are incorporated in the ADSDPP of the Dumagat Remontados IP community.
The LGUs of Argao, Alcoy and Dalaguete have each prepared their LCA Management Plan consistent with the goals and objectives of the Nug as Palinpinon Corridor. In Argao, the LCA Management Plan is also incorporated in the enhanced Forest Land Use Plan (FLUP). In Alcoy and Dalaguete, the FLUP has been prepared prior to NewCAPP, but it was ensured that the LCA Plan is consistent with their FLUPs. In each of these LGUs, the Municipal Councils have issued Resolutions adopting the LCA Management Plan.
In Mt. Hilong hilong, the CCP has been incorporated in the ADSDPP of the Mamanwa-Manobo IP community.
In Tawi-tawi, the LCA management plan was adopted by the LGU and budget for its implementation was integrated in the 2015 Annual Investment Plan of the LGU.
In Mt. Nacolod, the LCA Management Framework was prepared and adopted by the seven (7) Municipal LGUs and Provincial Council.
In the Polillo Group of Islands, the municipalities of Polillo, Burdeos and Panukulan who are among the first municipalities to establish LCAs have already integrated the LCA Management Plans in their CLUPs and are already updating their plans at present.
In the case of Mt. Kalatungan, the ICCA and CCP have been adopted by the Protected Area Management Board (PAMB). The updated PA Management Plan of Mt. Kalatungan Natural Park dedicates a section on management of ancestral domains within the PA.

description.narrative: Operational Manual for local management bodies

comment.narrative: Inadequate for use by existing PAMBs; no Manual yet for local management bodies of new conservation areas
Operational Manuals are implemented to strengthen capacities of local management bodies of existing PAs and new conservation areas

Achieved.
The Handbook for PAMB Operations and the accompanying training modules has been submitted and is now undergoing final review. The BMB will take on the roll out of the manual and training modules once finalized .
Weak for existing PAs; no M and E protocols for new conservation areas
PAWB and local PA/CA Managers and staff have capacities to undertake M and E and use this information for adaptive management

Achieved.
NewCAPP carried out a review of implementation of BMS in August 2013 which identified a set of recommendations for improvement. These were taken on by the Wildlife Resources Division. In addition, the GIZ-PAME is supporting the development of cost effective BD baseline and monitoring methods that consider the recommendation of the earlier NewCAPP study and the competency standards for PA sector.
NIPAS PA M and E system drafted. A discussion with BMB Senior Staff and other FAPs was held to review the NIPAS Program and the revised NIPAS M and E indicators and reference sheets. These will be integrated in the M and E System of the PA System Master Plan.

description.narrative: Awareness and support from stakeholders for national PA system

comment.narrative:
Achieved.
Proposed Legislations. The proposed PA Omnibus Bill will strengthen the legal status of 97 proclaimed PAs, into full gazzetted PAs, covering 2.6 Million hectares and 179,439 hectares of buffer zones. The Enhanced NIPAS Bill also contains a provision recognizing ICCAs within PAs. Congressman Baguilat also filed an ICCA Bill in Congress, followed by Senator Legarda at the Senate. The bill was approved by the Committee level. Next step, coordinate with the Committee Secretariat for the Plenary Discussion/s.
Funding Support from Various Sources. Since NewCAPP started in 2009, additional projects were implemented in the sector, with an estimated total funding commitment of USD 51.9 M. These are:
UNDP-GEF-BPP (USD 4.5 M)
GIZ-PAME (USD 9.9M)
USAID-B+WISER (USD 25 M)
UNDP-GEF-MKBA (USD 8 M)
UNDP-GEF-SGP (USD 4.5M)
Legislative Support. With ASoG, a briefing with Congress on the Second State of the PA Report was held on October 28, 2014. Those who attended the presentation expressed support to additional funding and the passage of the Omnibus Bill on PAs.
Reduction in Levels of Destructive Activities. The LCA Management Plans and ICCA/CCPs specify that there will be no destructive activities that will be allowed in these areas. EMB Memorandum Circular 005 dated July 2014 (Revised Guidelines for Coverage Screening and Standardized Requirements under the Philippines EIS System) has categorized LCAs and ancestral domains as environmentally critical areas.
In Mt. Hilong-hilong, the MGB representative requested a copy of the shape files of the ICCA site to designate it as no go zone for mining.
Number of proposed development projects rejected for being incompatible with PA and CA management objectives. 11 of NewCAPP sites have clearly stated in their management/conservation plans the prohibition of extractive/destructive activities within the conservation areas such mining. LGUs have likewise issued support policies such as:
-Polillo SB Resolutions nos. 119 2012, 069-2011 reiterated their strong opposition to mining and quarrying operations and similar activities within their jurisdiction.
-Mt. Nacolod the Provincial Board issued Resolution No. 740-s.2012 which disallows any form of mining activity in the LCA.
-In BBNP, the strength and unity of the tribe and community prevented the operation of CelloPhil and saved the forest. CelloPhil established pulp and paper processing plant in the 70s threatening the lush forests of BBNP. The main reason behind the resistance was the Bodong or traditional resources management in the area. Since then, no extractive activity has threatened the area. The Bodong and Lapat highlighted the ICCA and CCP of the Banao and Balatoc Tribe.
Nug as Palinpinon - In 2013, there was an incident of clearing in some parts of the Argao forests by the LGU for tourism purposes. However, this was immediately arrested upon the knowledge of the DENR Regional Office of Region 7 and a case was already filed in court to address the incident.
IEC Support for the 2 National Conferences. Case stories from NewCAPP sites prepared and distributed during the First National LCA Conference and Second National ICCA Conference held in October 2014. New exhibit panels on ICCA and LCA were prepared and launched during the conferences.
PMU also supported DENR Region 10 in the development of IEC materials for its 1st Protected Area Conference on July 22-23, 2014.
The NewCAPP website has been continuously updated with latest project activities and technical/project reports. From October 2011-June 2015, the average website daily hits is 1,237; the monthly average is 37,381. Since the website was established in October 2011, it has generated a total of 1.68 million hits by the end of June 2015.

description.narrative: Enhanced financial sustainability of the terrestrial PA system
National level capacity to manage financing of the PA system

comment.narrative: Limited capacity by PAWB to manage financing for national PA system
PAWB has improved capacity to use new tools and mechanisms to sustainably manage financing of national terrestrial PA system to include new CAs

Achieved.
Draft Addendum to DENR Administratve Order No. 2007-17 on the Rules and Regulations Governing Special Uses within Protected Areas (SAPA). NewCAPP commissioned a study on SAPA fees being collected in PAs in 2011 to establish a common methodology in computing SAPA fees across all PAs. A recommendation to increase fees from SAPA using market values of properties, thereby potentially increasing internally generated revenues across all PAs was presented and discussed with PAWB and DENR Undersecretary. These recommendations were translated into a draft Addendum to the existing Department Administrative Order (DAO) for the following objectives:
? To provide premium to ecosystem services provided by PAs, e.g., water production, which are limited resources;
? To generate revenues which can be utilized for improved management and operations of the protected area; thereby decreasing required national government subsidy;
? To serve as a regulatory tool or disincentive for increased resource uses beyond the carrying-capacities of PAs; and
? To increase local economic opportunities, e.g., increased local employment from eco-tourism establishments.
Recommendations for maximizing the potentials offered by existing financing instruments. A review of Department Administrative Order 2000-51 or the policy on PA user fees was undertaken to conduct an inventory of user fees being collected in three PAs, namely Mt. Apo Natural Park, Mt. Kanlaon Natural Park and Mt. Kitanglad Natural Park; constraints on not being able to maximize potentials of user fees; and recommendations on improving PA financing. The study recommended (i) improvement in implementation of DAO 2000-51 and (ii) promotion of other sustainable financing mechanisms.
Increased understanding of Integrated Protected Area Fund (IPAF) management and disbursment process of PA staff. A review of IPAF collections, procedures, and status of all 240 PAs was undertaken by the Project. A Technical Brief was prepared summarizing the findings and disseminated to DENR audiences, and other stakeholders. A total of 120 PAs from 200 participants attended the training in 2012; while 353 participants from 131 PAs attended the IPAF training in 2015.
Defined procedures and accountability centers in implementation of RA 10629. NewCAPP provided technical assistance to BMB in developing the implementing guidelines of Republic Act 10629 or “An Act Providing for the Retention by PAMB of 75% of Revenues accruing to IPAF, Amending for the Purpose Section 16 of RA 7586 known as NIPAS Act of 1992”. Signed in September 26, 2013, RA 10629 provides for retention of 75% of PA income at PAMB level. To set operational procedures on how RA 10629 would have to be implemented by PAs, NewCAPP assisted BMB in working with DBM-Bureau E and BTr-NCAD in crafting the DENR-DBM Joint Memorandum Circular (JMC) 2014-1 which was signed in September 26, 2014 by Secretary Paje of DENR, Secretary Abad of DBM, with Congressman Teves as key witness.
Improved collaboration among donor-funded Projects providing technical assistance to the Bureau on financing. NewCAPP convened the PA Financing FAPs Thematic Group where an agreement is reached to work together on PA Financing Roadmap. The National PA Financing Roadmap which intends to provide overall direction and strategy for sustaining financing of PAs and other conservation areas was included in the PA System Master Plan component.

While the target scores were not met, there has been improvement in PA Financing scores in all aspects by a total of 21 percentage points compared to the baseline. While the Project has accomplished all outputs under Outcome 3, more needs to be done to improve capacity for system wide financing such as formulation and implementation of PA Business Plan. The results of the PA Financing Study has been translated into a Guide. However, BMB has to roll this out to the rest of the PAs. These requirements are being put together under the PA System Master Plan.

description.narrative: Number of sites with capacities for financing, business planning and cost effective management

comment.narrative: Nil
At least 3 new PA/CAs have capacities for site level financing, business planning and cost effective management

Achieved.
A PA business planning process was rolled-out in eighteen selected PAs through Sustainable Financing of Protected Areas Project of WB-GEF NSP-ENRMP. NewCAPP developed the Terms of Reference of this Project and heavily supported PAWB in the procurement process and implementation of the said Project. Following the business planning process introduced by REECS - the Projects contractor - NewCAPP documented the process and integrated it in the LCA Guide developed and published by the Project. The business planning module was also demonstrated in Mt. Nacolod in Southern Leyte and Mts. Nug-as and Lantoy in Cebu as part of the LCA management planning process.

The two waves of IPAF trainings (2012 and 2015) benefitted 300 participants from 131 PAs through IPAF retention policies, and sharing of successful mechanisms to raise PA financing. The IPAF Handbook will benefit all PAs.

description.narrative: To demonstrate how Local Government Units (LGUs), with enhanced capacities, and working together with local and national partners, can plan and manage economic activities and growth in ways that meet landscape-level biodiversity conservation and sustainable use objectives in critical biogeographic regions
Population estimates of at least three critically endangered species in three demonstration sites

comment.narrative: Expected to decrease by at least 10% by end-project
No decline in populations of tamaraw in Siburan forests; Visayan hornbill in Central Panay and NNNP; and Philippine eagle in Mt. Hamiguitan

Mt Siburan in the municipality of Sablayan in the province of Mindoro Occidental is part of the habitat range of the Tamaraw that includes the adjoining Mt Aruyan Malati also in Sablayan and nearby Mt Iglit-Baco in Mindoro Oriential. Tamarraw used to be abundant throughout the island of Mindoro numbering around 10,000 in the 1900s. The most recent Tamaraw count by DENR-Tamaraw Conservation Program (TCP, April 2013) recorded 345 individuals but count stations were mostly concentrated on the southwestern portion of Mts Iglit-Baco.
The 2004 survey by Haribon Foundation in Mt Siburan reported tracks and fecal evidence of the species along the banks of Malate River. The TCP survey in Mt Aruyan-Malati estimated that around 11 tamaraw individuals were in the area. According to TCP there is no official report confirming the presence of tamaraa in Mt Siburan for some anecdotal records sometime in year 2000 regarding the presence of a Tamaraw bull in the area. The 2013 survey in Aruyan recorded ethnobiological data but failed to locate any physical evidence of the presence of the species in Mt Siburan. An ethno-biodiversity survey currently is beind conducted by Haribon, the BPP site partner to determine the number of tamaraws in Mt. Siburan.
The biodiversity survey in Central Panay Mountains (CPM) in 2014 validated the presence of Visayan hornbill in CPM. The biodiversity study conducted in Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP) counted 14 Visayan Tarictic Hornbill and 3 Rufous headed hornbill in the area.
The biodiversity assessment conducted in selected sampling sites within in Mt. Hamiguitan confirmed the presence of a Philippine Eagle in Barangay Surop. The eagle is probably Cabuaya, the chick of the eagles Cabu and Aya of Mati, due to the green leg band and attached transmitter.

description.narrative: Extent of habitat fragmentation in unprotected PAs/KBAs in eight demonstration sites

comment.narrative: Expected to increase by at least10% by end-project
No net increase in fragmentation in 287,000 hectares of unprotected PAs/KBAs in eight demonstration sites

The patch analysis was used to determine the level of fragmentation in the eight (8) demonstration sites. Patch analysis deals with the threshold sizes of habitat patches beyond which they might be considered highly degraded and fragmented. This can be expressed as the proportion of habitat that is in continuous patches over, 100 square-kilometers within a particular PA/KBA.
The total area of forest patch for each demonstration sites are as follows:
Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area (NeCKBA): 141,840 hectares or 79.9% patch
Quirino Protected Landscapes (QPL): 93,458 hectares or 80% patch
Malampaya Sound Protected Landscapes and Seascapes (MSPLS): 23,004 hectares or 43.14% patch
Mt. Siburan: 2, 473 hectares or 59.71% patch
Mt. Hamiguitan: 16,900 or 76.24% patch
Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area (LMKBA): 12,139 hectares or 7.98% patch
Central Panay Mountains (CPM): 76,103 hectares or 99.9%
Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP): 27,690 hectares or 99.97%

description.narrative: Number of hectares in production landscapes/ waterscapes under sustainable management

comment.narrative: No increase during the period

At least additional 10,000 hectares under sustainable management but not yet certified
At least additional 800 hectares and 8 production systems under certified production practices that meet sustainability and biodiversity standards

A total of 128,138 hectares have been identified and classified/zoned as sustainable use management areas. The classification/zonation of these areas was part of the mainstreaming of biodiversity in the local land use plans of the LGUs in the eight demonstration sites. The sustainable use management areas shall be developed and managed to improve the land productivity to support agricultural production and agri-based livelihood opportunities through sustainable upland management strategies and land and water use conservation. These sustainable use management areas coverage are as follows:
Quirino (Nagtipunan and Maddela):31,124 hectares
Cagayan: 60,936 hectares Calatrava, Negros Occidental: 2,362 hectares
Taytay, Palawan: 33,716 hectares.
The additional 10,000 hectares that will be subject to certification will be specified from these areas delineated as sustainable use management zones.
To date, about 1,209 hectares in the eight project sites were assessed and documented as potential sites of farm areas practicing biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices. These areas upon initial assessment meet the standards of biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices. Further assessment and documentation of the areas will be done upon once DENR and DA approve the policy, standards, and certifications schemes for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices is obtained from DENR and DA.
The standards for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices have been drafted and would be finalized following approval of the Joint Administrative Order of DA and DENR on the promotion of BD-friendly agricultural practices in PAs and KBAs and wider agricultural landscape is issued. Subsequently, the BPP-PMU will discuss with DA Team strategies to meet the target of at least 800 hectares and 8 production systems under certified production practices that meet sustainability and biodiversity standards.

description.narrative: National-level systems, policies, tools and capacities are in place to support LGU-level biodiversity conservation efforts
Agencies with policies and associated capacity to conduct biodiversity impact assessment of sectoral policies and plans

comment.narrative: None
DA and DENR are routinely conducting biodiversity impact assessments of sectoral policies and plans by year 4.

The applicability of biodiversity impact assessments using the biodiversity-focused Strategic Environment Assessment (BDSEA) process will be pilot-tested to DENR-Biodiversity Management Bureau’s (BMB) plans, policies and programs.
The BDSEA has gone through several consultations with the Technical Review Committee of BMB. This was also presented and discussed with key National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) officers and staff for possible issuance of an Executive Order for adoption and government-wide use of BDSEA.
The draft Department Administrative Order (DAO) on BDSEA was presented and discussed with the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) Policy Technical Working Group (PTWG). The DENR PTWG recommended for the issuance of a Memorandum Circular (MC) in lieu of the proposed DAO for the adoption of the BDSEA Manual of Procedures (MoP) within the DENR.
The MoP for BDSEA was reviewed by the BMB Senior Staff and Technical Review Committee. Pending the approval of the MC for the application of the MoP, the BMB-review committee suggested to have a Technical Bulletin to have an enabling document to apply the manual at the BPP sites.
The Technical Bulletin was prepared and for signature of BMB Director.

description.narrative: Programmes and policies to support biodiversity friendly agricultural production in critical landscapes

comment.narrative:
No agrobiodiversity programs in AFMA plan
National Action Plan for Sustainable Land management (NAP-SLM) do not include agrobiodiversity projects in buffer zones of PAs and KBAs
Standards and certification schemes limited to organic agricultural production
Activities to promote conservation and utilization of indigenous crops

Updated AFMA Plan incorporates agrobiodiversity programs.
Revised NAP-SLM includes agrobiodiversity projects in buffer zones of PAs or KBAs.
Standards and certification system for biodiversity friendly production systems in place
Policy and program developed in DA to promote conservation and utilization of indigenous crops

The Department of Agriculture (DA) has proposed that instead of updating the AFMA plan, a Joint Administrative Order be promulgated because the updating of the AFMA Plan is not being done on a yearly basis. Furthermore, the AFMA covers the wider agricultural landscapes that covers various stakeholders while the area of focus for mainstreaming biodiversity will be within and around the Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas. The request was reflected in a DA letter to the DENR dated July 2014. The DA-DENR Joint Administrative Order: Mainstreaming Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices In and Around Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas and Promoting the Same in Wider Agricultural Landscapes is subject to parallel review of DENR Policy Technical Working Group (PTWG) and DA Policy Review Committee.
The draft National Action Plan for Sustainable Land Management (NAP-SLM) has been prepared which provides for robust discussion on biodiversity. The concern on biodiversity is part of the Strategic Objective 2 of NAP-SLM: To regenerate and rehabilitate watershed landscapes and their resources for ecosystem services enhancement. The NAP-SLM also incorporates two (2) sub-programs of the Thematic Program 3: Watershed Landscape Management and Rehabilitation includes biodiversity as follows: 1) Sustainable management of forest resources; and 2) Promotion of SLM for forest resources conservation and management. It also include the listings of completed and ongoing projects on biodiversity in buffer zones of Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas.
The said draft NAP-SLM is being reviewed by Department of Agriculture and targeted for approval by end of 2015.
Drafted the Philippine National Standard for Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices. This standard describes the requirements for Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices for the production of agricultural and fishery commodities [in and around PAs and KBAs]. Likewise, this standard provides a mechanism to define Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices and when complied with, it also enables producers to label their product accordingly. However, the standard does not cover procedures for verification, such as inspection or certification of products.
Through the ITPGRFA project, the protocols for on-farm conservation of traditional varieties will be developed. The basis for this protocol will be the available technical information in scientific literature as well as practices applicable to the community setting. Other possible reference in drafting the said protocol are the good agricultural production and conservation practices which is biodiversity friendly observed during field studies and Community Field School.
To date, as a result of the study conducted by ITPGRFA project, the information on the incentives for promotion of conservation as a result of the key informant interviews with producers, market actors, and institutional actors showed minimal incentives for promotion of traditional rice and root crops.
The elements of the draft strategic action plan (SAP) for the conservation and sustainable use of traditional varieties of rice, yam, taro and sweet potato were identified through the preparatory phase, stakeholder analysis and field studies in the six pilot barangays in the four provinces covered by the ITPGRFA project. The elements of the SAP were identified and will be the basis of the draft that will be prepared.

description.narrative: Systems and procedures for implementation of new regulations of trade in wild plant and animal resources

comment.narrative: Department Order issued
System established for surveillance, monitoring, and mapping the sources of illegally traded wild plants and animals

The system being established for surveillance, monitoring, and mapping the sources of illegally traded wild plants and animals is in a form of partnerships with various national government agencies that are have mandates, capabilities and procedures in detecting, preventing and restricting illegal trade and transport of wildlife.
The DENR together with the following agencies: Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Agriculture-Bureau of Animal Industry (DA-BAI), Department of Agriculture-Bureau of Plant Industry (DA-BPI), Department of Trade and Industry, Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board (LTRFB), Land Transportation Office (LTO), Maritime Industry Authority (MIA), Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAB), Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB), Philippine Coast Guard (PCG), Philippine Ports Authority (PPA), Light Rail Transit Authority (LRTA), Philippine National Railways (PNR), Philippine National Police (PNP), National Bureau of Investigation (NBI), Office for Transportation Security (OTS), Bureau of Customs (BoC), and National Prosecution Service (NPS) is in the process of creating an Inter-agency Committee. Initial meetings have been carried out to fine tune the Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) providing for, among other things, the creation of the inter-agency committee and specifying the responsibilities of partner agencies.
The BMB and BPP-PMU successfully convened a consultation meeting with these agencies last April 7, 2015 review the final draft of the MoA. The final draft of the MoA is now being refined to incorporate the inputs solicited during this meeting.

description.narrative: Policies to encourage investments in biodiversity friendly business

comment.narrative: None

Policy in place at DTI
Priority biodiversity business identified in DTI policy documents.

Incorporated the biodiversity friendly business/enterprise concept in the Memorandum Circular No. 2015- 01 General Policies and Specific Guidelines to Implement the Investment Priorities Plan (IPP) 2014 – 2016 under the Part XII. Support to Environmental Protection and Conservation to encourage registered enterprises to protect and conserve biodiversity in their respective area and/or activities and promote biodiversity-friendly businesses/enterprises.
Revised the Joint Administrative Order of Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), Department of Tourism (DOT), and Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) on “Adopting Biodiversity-Friendly Business and Enterprise Framework and Criteria” as well as the Framework and Criteria for Assessing Biodiversity-Friendly Business to incorporate comments and concerns of the BMB Technical Review Committee and provided clearer description of the industry categories as well as indicators and criteria.
PAWB biodiversity information system has limited data and information that can be shared with LGUs, conservation NGOs and other development agencies.
A Knowledge Management System established at PAWB with computerized data storage and retrieval system that can be accessed on-line by LGUs, conservation NGOs and other development agencies.
A Knowledge Management System (KMS) established by BPP at BMB is a web-based type database and information source, this can be accessed at www.philbiodiversitypartnerships.com.

description.narrative: LGUs in critical biogeographic regions with local regulations and capacity to implement policies on wildlife trade

comment.narrative: Nil

10 LGUs with local Ordinances to support regulation of local endemics
10 LGUs with staff trained on policies and procedures governing wildlife trade
Local coordinating bodies established with DENR, wildlife enforcement agents and volunteers to strengthen regulation of wildlife trade

1 LGU (Calatrava) with local ordinances (Local Environment Code) to support regulation of local endemics. Ongoing preparation of Baggao, Cagayan LEC.
Two (2) LGUs (Calatrava in NNNP and Baggao in NeCKBA) have already conducted workshops for the preparation of Local Environment Code (LEC) that provide detail on regulation of local endemics under the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act (Republic Act No. 9147) while a LEC orientation was conducted for the remaining five (5) LGUs within NeCKBA.
Two (2) LGUs (Alegria, Surigao Del Norte and Santiago, Agusan Del Norte ) provided their existing Local Environment Code to Lake Mainit BPP team for assessment and further enhancement to include details on regulation of local endemics.
25 LGUs with staff trained on policies and procedures governing wildlife trade. The following LGUs are as follows:
Malampaya Sound Protected Landscapes and Seascapes (Municipality of Taytay, Province of Palawan)
Central Panay Mountains (Municipalities of Libacao and Madalag, Province of Aklan; Municipalities of Barbaza, Bugasong, Culasi, Lauan, San Remigio, Valderrama, Province of Antique; Municipalities of Jamindan, Tapaz, Province of Capiz; Municipalities of Calinog, Janiuay and Lambunao, Province of Iloilo)
Mt. Hamiguitan (Mati City, Municipalities of San Isidro and Governor Generoso, Province of Davao Oriental)
Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area (Province of Surigao del Norte, Municipalities of: Tubod, Sison, Mainit and Allegria
Province of Agusan del Norte, Municipalities of: Kitcharao, Jabonga, Santiago and Tubay)
Local Coordinating bodies to strengthen regulation of wildlife trade were established at:
Malampaya Sound Protected Landscape (MSPLS)
Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP)
Lake Mainit Development Alliance (LMKBA)

description.narrative: LGUs with regulatory structures and incentive systems to encourage the development of biodiversity-friendly businesses, including investor codes of conduct

comment.narrative: Nil
10 LGUs in project sites with regulatory structures, incentive systems, investor codes of conduct and programs and budgets promoting BD-friendly business.

7 out of 10 target LGUs in project sites passed the Local Investment and Incentive Code (LIIC). The LIIC is a document that articulates the local government’s investment policies and programs, Investments Priority Areas (IPAs), and local incentives (fiscal and non-fiscal) available to domestic and foreign investors, and the mechanics for availing them. The LIIC is an instrument for attracting, retaining, expanding and diversifying investments in the local economy, is supportive of local, regional and national economic development, and is developed through a multi-stakeholder process. While ongoing technical assistance on LIIC formulation is being done in Taytay, San Vicente, Governor Genoroso and Mati City.
The following LGUs passed LIIC as ordinance:
Quirino Protected Landscapes
Saguday
Diffun
Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area (NeCKBA)
Sta. Teresita
Buguey
Lal-lo
Mt. Siburan
Sablayan
Mt.Hamiguitan
San Isidro

description.narrative: Mechanisms and capacities for intra LGU knowledge sharing on mainstreaming biodiversity

comment.narrative: Mechanisms exist for intra LGU sharing on environment programs and performance but not on biodiversity

Mechanism and network established to regularly share lessons on mainstreaming biodiversity
New national policy proposals formulated/approved based on lessons from LGUs/project sites
Improved capacity by LGUs to advocate improved policies

Strengthened the Local Project Site Committee for inter-Local Government Unit sharing of best practices.
Ongoing organization of Biodiversity Network (Bd-Net), a sustainability platform for advocacy/information, education and communication and capacity building activities across stakeholders. The network will also ensure sustained efforts in terms of knowledge exchange and sharing.
As response to the Midterm Evaluators’ recommendation, the BMB and BPP-PMU will convene a round table discussion series as part of the knowledge sharing process /event series. This will serve as a culmination activity for the project to present and share significant results and lessons learned and draw up new policy program and program proposals. The project will provide assistance in the formulation of improved templates for key LGU policies and ordinances based on the project experience in mainstreaming, biodiversity friendly agriculture practices and business as well as wildlife trade.

description.narrative: Systems, policies, tools and capacities for landscape-level biodiversity conservation and sustainable development are applied at eight pilot sites covering at least 700,000 hectares across five critical biogeographic regions (Luzon, Palawan, Negros-Panay, Mindoro, Mindanao).
LGU development plans at project sites complying with SEA approach, as well as landscape level natural resources management

comment.narrative:
LGUs do not apply SEAs in local development planning
PA management plans and FLUPs not integrated in CLUPs

At least 20% of LGUs in the project sites apply SEA in their development planning.
At least 20% of LGUs in the project sites integrate biodiversity conservation zoning (PA or KBA zoning) in their CLUP.

As mentioned in Outcome 2, about 12% of the total LGUs covered by the project were given Orientation Training on simplified BDSEA. Orientation will still be done to other LGUs.
As per recommendation of the Midterm Evaluators and subject to GEF approval, instead of 8 LGUs (at least 20% of LGUs) focal attention shall be provided to at least two (2) LGUs. Accordingly, this proposal will allow the BPP-PMU to provide more time in fine-tuning delivery systems; documentation of lessons learned; and facilitating sharing and reflection among early practitioners of SEA. The PMU will focus on Training and Coaching in the use of the simplified BDSEA for LGUs this 3rd and 4th quarter of 2015.
56% of LGUs in the project sites integrate biodiversity conservation zoning (PA or KBA zoning) in their CLUP.
Update on the mainstreaming work:
CLUPs of LGUs in Quirino Protected Landscape and Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area were already approved
CLUP of Toboso is subject for review
CLUP of Buguey is subject to Public hearing
CLUP of Sta. Teresita, Baggao and Culasi are at the level of project prioritization
CLUP of Calatrava is for final writing
CLUP of Silay is under Options formulation
CLUP of Sebaste is at the level of Land Use policy formulation and sectoral studies
CLUP of Governor Generoso at the level of Land use policy and sectoral planning
San Isidro, Davao Oriental, Gattaran and Gonzaga, Cagayan provided their reference materials for environment sector

description.narrative: Inter LGU cooperation in planning and regulation of natural resource use

comment.narrative:
Municipal and City LGUs plan separately and do not coordinate and harmonize their plans.
Provincial Land Use Committees oversee and approves municipal and city land use plans.
LGUs within PAs or KBAs do not jointly adopt any economic PES instruments

At least two transboundary conservation areas established
LGUs in the project sites (at least 3 jointly managed landscapes) harmonize their development plans for natural resource use in biodiversity landscapes that cut across their administrative boundaries.
LGUs in the project sites sharing PA or KBA areas jointly adopt resource planning tools such as FLUP, ICRMP, ecological zoning.
At least 3 Provincial CLUPs in the project sites adopt the planning tools for biodiversity conservation.
PES instrument developed and tested in at least one biodiversity landscape.

Two (2) Transboundary Conservation Areas will be established in Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area (NECKBA) covering six (6) LGUs and Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area (LMKBA) covering eight (4) LGUs each in Agusan and Surigao Del Norte.
Protected Area Management Plan (PAMP) for Quirino Protected Landscape (QPL) is being enhanced and finalized. The PAMP for Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP) was enhanced.
Taytay and San Vicente LGUs in Malampaya Sound Protected Landscapes jointly adopt the Forest Land Use Plan (FLUP), ICRMP and Environmental Critical Area Network (ECAN) Framework planning. ECAN Framework planning was initiated by Palawan Council for Sustainable Development (PCSD).
Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) instruments on Watershed Management and Water Systems were developed and pilot-tested in Quirino Protected Landscapes (QPL).
s
Three new conservation areas established covering 15 LGUs

Delineated 2 (two) new conservation areas as Local Conservation Areas in Tubod and Mainit, Surigao Del Norte.
Drafted ordinance declaring the municipalities of Alegria and Kitcharao as Local Conservation Areas.
1 LGU (Lambunao) in Central Panay Mountains approved the Resolution declaring 2,318.42 hectares as Critical Habitat this aim to conserve and protect the wildlife species within, regulate the collection and trade of wildlife, address the threats and effectively manage.
1 LGU (Sebaste) in Central Panay Mountains drafted an Ordinance Providing for the Establishment of a Critical Habitat (2,567hectares) in the Municipality of Sebaste, Province of Antique defining the Area of Coverage, Creating Institutional Management Mechanisms, Defining its Powers and Functions and for Other Purposes
No increase over project period

At least 5,000 farmers adopting biodiversity friendly agricultural practices
Additional 2,000 farmers and producers meeting certification standards

About two (2) hectares of demonstration farm for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices was established in Sitio Mahucdam, Bgy. Kapayaan, Tubod, Surigao Norte.
The project provided assistance in the establishment of a demonstration farm covering around 2.17 hectares in Sitio Managaksak, Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Murcia, Negros Occidental.
Same assistance was provided to Brgy. Eden, Cabarroguis, Quirino in the establishment of 22. 9 hectares of demonstration farms following the biodiversity-friendly principles.
Based on assessment using the biodiversity-friendly agricultural practices framework and principles, about 893 farmers are practicing biodiversity-friendly agricultural practices.
Completed profiles of additional model sites for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices. Conducted initial suitability assessment of the proposed model/demonstration farm site in MSPLS in Palawan and in Mt. Siburan in Sablayan, Mindoro Occidental.
The standards for biodiversity-friendly agricultural practices is still being finalized.

description.narrative: Pressures from overharvesting of wild resources

comment.narrative: Expected to increase over total area of KBAs/PAs in project sites by 10% each year

Pressure reduced in PAs totaling at least 260,000 hectares
No net reduction in population of key species in selected sites
(e.g., hornbill, Philippine eagle, etc.)

The policy on the guidelines for the harmonized implementation of regulations on the domestic trade in wildlife is still under review of the policy review committee of DENR.
The protection and rehabilitation of remaining forests and wildlife habitats were included in the CLUPs and CDPs of LGUs that participated in the BD mainstreaming work.
To reduced the pressure in Protected Areas totaling at least 260,000 hectares, the Local Government Units were encouraged to have an enhanced Local Environment Code (LEC) that elaborate the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act (Republic Act No. 9147) which states that LGUs shall initiate conservation measures for endemic species in their areas.
To date, the status of LEC preparations are as follows:
1 LGU (Calatrava) with local ordinances (Local Environment Code) to support regulation of local endemics. Ongoing preparation of Baggao, Cagayan LEC.
Two (2) LGUs (Calatrava in NNNP and Baggao in NeCKBA) have already conducted workshops for the preparation of Local Environment Code (LEC) that provide detail on regulation of local endemics under the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act (Republic Act No. 9147) while a LEC orientation was conducted for the remaining five (5) LGUs within NeCKBA.
Two (2) LGUs (Alegria, Surigao Del Norte and Santiago, Agusan Del Norte ) provided their existing Local Environment Code to Lake Mainit BPP team for assessment and further enhancement to include details on regulation of local endemics.
Completed the Biodiversity Assessments in the eight (8) sites, biodiversity monitoring will be done in 2016.

description.narrative: Private investments in biodiversity friendly business in selected project sites

comment.narrative: Nil

At least four businesses engaged in biodiversity-friendly enterprises in project sites by year 5.
At least four producer groups in PAs/KBAs adhere to LGU investor codes of conduct

Based on the assessment done using the biodiversity-friendly business/enterprise framework and assessment tool, the following enterprises have potential for scale-up:
Bakong Enterprise
Marine products in Buguey, Cagayan
Quirino Ginger Tea, Bamboo, Coffee, Banana and Cornstarch
Pandan leaves and bamboo small furnitures in Malampaya
Souvenir items production (made of nito, nipay seeds and tiger grass)
Organic vegetables in Gawahon
Almaciga resin tapping in Mt. Hamiguitan
Status to date:
Ongoing ecological and feasibility study for the bakong enterprise
Ongoing feasibility study for marine products in Buguey, Cagayan
Ongoing formulation of Cooperative systems and procedures for the Malampaya Pancol Multipurpose Cooperative (MPMC)
Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) signed with Mati City for the provision of funds to support expansion of almaciga resin production.
To institutionalize and sustain support to the identified biodiversity-friendly business in the project sites, various agreements with the private sectors, peoples’ organizations and local consolidators are being finalized, the status are as follows:
Memoranda of Understanding between private sectors and Biodiversity Management Bureau are for signing, the private sectors are as follows: Association of Negros Producers and Freshstart Organics in Negros Occidental; Antique Development Foundation in CPM.
Tripartite MoU between Quirino Provincial Local Government Units (QPLGU), Philippine Coffee Alliance, Inc. and (PCAI) Mataga-ay Sustainable Resources Development and Conservation Association (MASREDECA) for signing.
Tripartite Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between DENR through BMB, QPLGU and Bote Central for signing.

description.narrative: Communities receiving incentives for shifting to sustainable practices

comment.narrative: Nil

Conservation agreements in place with at least two community groups in CPM and NNNP
PES schemes negotiated with two more community groups in other sites in PPLS and NNNP
10 communities engaged in sustainable livelihoods

The transboundary planning in CPM was deferred due to lack of interest of the LGUs to pursue the said planning. The Project Management Unit (PMU) and Local Responsible Partner tried to convene for the Orientation Workshop on Transboundary Planning for Central Panay Mountains (CPM) the Provinces of Iloilo, Antique, Aklan and Capiz but only the Province of Iloilo was receptive, thus, the Orientation Workshop was pursued last July 17-18, 2014 for Iloilo, however, the succeeding workshops were not convened due to lack of interest and unavailability of the respective sectoral representatives to participate. The conservation agreements in CPM however, is covered in the Critical Habitat Declaration and Management Plan for instance, goal number 3, in the proposed Critical Habitat Management Plan for Lambunao elaborate the sustainably manage human activities through community-based resource management.
In addition, Conservation Agreement (CAs) are being done in Mt. Hamiguitan in partnerships with the existing projects of Philippine Eagle Foundation. The project provided
complementary support to the community-based management of the Philippine Eagle Sanctuary by providing
funds for the pilot-testing of a Public-Private-Community (PPC) partnership through
Conservation Agreements (CAs). This
aims to provide forms of ‘conservation
incentives’ to local communities who act
as managers of biodiversity areas and
have shown clear conservation outcomes
out of their management work. In return, the communities pledged to do
their share in conservation through
reforestation in their own farm lots.
PES schemes in NNNP in partnership with the Provincial Environment and Management Office (PEMO) will still be identified.
Around nine (9) peoples’ organizations /communities are engaging in biodiversity-friendly livelihoods. These are as follows:
1. MASREDECA (Mataga-ay Sustainable Resources Development and Conservation Association) in QPL
2. MPMC (Malampaya Pancol Multipurpose Cooperative) in MSPLS
3. SIKAP (Samahang Inaasahan ng mga Katutubo sa Alimanguan, Palawan) in MSPLS
4. PAFISFA (Patag Farmers Integrated Social Foresty Association) in NNNP
5. VISFA (Victorias Integrated Social Forestry Association) in NNNP
6. TIGMAMUGON (Tigbobolo Mangunguma, Mangingisda,Mamumugon) Association/ Tigbobolo Bamboocraft Association, Brgy. Tigbobolo, Culasi, Antique in CPM
7. SJVPA (Multipurpose Cooperative in Santiago, San Jose Producers Association in Mainit, Lake Mainit KBA
8. EPATLEA (Eco-Park Agri-Tourism Livelihood Enterprise Association n Kitcharao, Lake Mainit KBA
9. LATAGG (Lumad Almaciga Tappers’ Association of Gov. Generoso) in Mt. Hamiguitan

description.narrative: Data and knowledge management systems to support local initiatives

comment.narrative:
Some LGUs have isolated data and knowledge management systems but not linked to national system
Insufficient data to adequately monitor status and trends in biodiversity and impacts of development programs

Rapid resource assessments completed/updated in eight project sites
Population estimates of critically endangered species in eight sites determined
Monitoring system in place to determine progress in meeting conservation plan objectives, linked to knowledge management system
Increased public awareness and positive support to conservation efforts among local stakeholders
LGU level data and knowledge management system enhanced
LGU staff trained in use of data and knowledge management system
LGUs able to access and share data and information in national system

Rapid resource assessments in the eight sites were completed and ecological profiles were updated.
Population estimates as of (2013-2014) of the critically endangered species of both fauna and flora in the eight sites are as follows:
Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area
Fauna:
Oriolus isabellae (Isabela Oriole): 3 ind.
Flora:
Hopea cagayanensis (Narek): 18 ind.
Shorea polysperma (Taguile): 94 ind
Shorea contorta (White lauan): 66 ind
Shorea negrosensis (Red Lauan): 82 ind
Parashorea malaanonan (Bagtikan): 21 ind.
Shorea palosapis (Mayapis): 190 ind.
Shorea astylosa (Yakal): 42 ind.
Hopea malibato (Yakal-kaliot): 48 ind.
Shorea guiso (Guijo): 14 ind.
Dipterocarpus grandiflorus (Apitong): 8 ind.
Anisopthera thurifera (Palosapis): 19 ind.
Shorea malibato (Yakal malibato): 4 ind.
Hopea acuminata (Mangachapui): 1 ind.
Shorea assamica (Mangasinoro): 2 ind.
Tristaniopsis decorticata (Malabayabas): 6 ind.
Toona calantas (Kalantas): 2 ind.
Quirino Protected Landscapes
Fauna:
Oriolus isabellae (Isabela Oriole) Pithecophaga jefferyi (Philippine Eagle)
No recorded sightings as of biodiversity assessment survey conducted last 2013-2014.
Flora:
Dipterocarpus gracilis (Panau)
Dipterocarpus grandiflorus (Apitong)
Dipterocarpus hasselti
Dipterocarpus kunstleri
Dipterocarpus validus (Hagakhak)
Hopea acuminata (Mangachapui)
Shorea contorta (White lauan)
Shorea guiso (Guijo)
Shorea negrosensis (Red Lauan)
Shorea palosapis (Mayapis)
Shorea polysperma (Taguile)
Mt. Siburan
Fauna:
Centropus steerii (Black-hooded Coucal): 85 ind.
Gallicolumba platenae (Mindoro Bleeding Heart): 1 ind.
Cacatua haematuropygia (Philippine Cockatoo): no sightings as of survey conducted
Bubalus mindorensis (Tamaraw): presence/count to be validated through enthno-biosurvey.
Malampaya Sound Protected Landscape and Seascape:
Based on the survey conducted on the Palawan forest turtle in So. Maubog, Bgy. Alacalian, Taytay, Palawan, 28 Palawan forest turtle were captured. Out of 28 individuals, there are 4 males, 4 females and 20 are juvenile whereby the sexual characteristic is not yet differentiated. The baseline photo identification survey of the critically endangered Irrawaddy Dolphin (Orcaella brevirostris) using Darwin software revealed that there are 47 individuals within Malampaya Sound through photo identification based on their dorsal fin.
Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area
Based on the biodiversity assessment survey conducted in the municipalities covering the Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area, two (2) Tarictic Hornbill (Penelopides panini ) were sighted in Jabonga, Agusan del Norte. The presence of Manggachapui or dalingdingan (Hopea acuminata), one of the critically endangered species of flora are found in Jabonga, Santiago, Kitcharao. While the Rafflesia mixta was found in Mainit, Surigao del Norte. A total of 7 Silvery Kingfisher (Alcedo argentata) , six (6) White-collared Fruit Bat (Megaerops wetmorei ), 21 Mindanao Horned Frog (Megophrys stejnegeri), and Mangkuno (Xantostemon verdugonianus) classified as vulnerable were recorded within Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area, aside from these the almaciga (Agathis philippinensis), an endangered species were also found in Tubod, Surigao del Norte.
Drafted the Framework for the local biodiversity M&E System (LBMES).
The design and manual for local biodiversity M&E System (LBMES) for LGUs, report on the pilot-testing of the LBMES and Implementation Plan and enabling document for the installation and operationalization of the LBMES within DILG and the LGUs still ongoing.
Continous advocacy and awareness activities in various forms e.g. exhibits, knowledge products, paper presentations (on preliminary results of biodiversity-friendly business/enterprise in Convention on Biological Diversity Side Event in Pyeongchang Korea and Asean Social Forestry Network Conference for ASEAN Economic Community in Inle Lake, Shan State, Myanmar).

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Extent to which detailed hazard maps are developed in project sites for better risk assessment 2. Increased lead time for flood warning at the community level 3. Information on vulnerable population and their socioeconomic information are available as basis for design of programs and projects 4. Availability of a local Climate and Disaster Risk Management knowledge management system 5. Number of communities in target sites with alternative livelihood activities and/or adjustments in farming and fishing activities/operations implemented (2015) 6. Number of communities in target sites availing of risk financing options/insurance (2015) 7. Number of communities in target sites with an established Knowledge Resource Center Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) (2015)

comment.narrative: 1. Not adequately - Flood susceptibility maps at 1:50,000 scale in Cagayan de Oro and Iligan City, no storm surge maps for Baganga, Boston and Cateel, no severe wind map for the provinces of Compostela Valley and Davao Oriental [2012] 2. Community-based and managed early warning systems non-existent for target sites [2011] 3. Community-based monitoring system data are incomplete and not geo-referenced [2012] 4. Information sharing and updating among data users and generators are very limited [2011] 5. 0 {2014] 6. 0 [2014] 7. 0 {2014]

1. Largely - Final climate-enhanced flood hazard maps for Cagayan de Oro and Iligan City developed from watershed modelling/analysis and flood modelling of Cagayan de Oro, Iponan, and Mandulog; Final storm surge map for Baganga, Boston, and Cateel prepared from better topographic and bathymetric data; Preliminary severe wind map for the provinces of Compostela Valley and Davao Oriental developed. 2. Community-based and managed early warning systems for flood, landslide are established in priority sites 3. Development of exposure database (ClimEx.db) with disaggregated and geo-referenced socioeconomic and physical data sets for CDO and Iligan Cities 4. Establishment of local Climate/Disaster Risk Knowledge Center in Iligan City and Cagayan de Oro 5. 1 6. 1 7. 1

None yet. The project has just approved its first set of proposals. The first proposals have big potential for starting out new landscapes. At this point, proposals are being developed using the landscape strategy. The project has been in constant dialogue with local CSOs. So far, five potential landscapes have been identified: (1) Northern Samar, connecting the Samar Island National Park and the BiRi LaRosa Protected Seascape; (3) the stretch of forests, ancestral domains and coastal areas of San Luis up to Maria Aurora in Aurora Province; (3) the environs of the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park, which can serve as its buffer zone; (4) the unprotected Victoria-Anepaan Mountain Range in southern Palawan; and (5) the Mt. Caraballo-Mt. Palali ranges, which connects Sierra Madre and Cordillera mountain ranges. Site-based consultations and project developments are in various stages.

description.narrative: Poverty reduction by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable agriculture-based rural communities in Mindanao through climate risk transfer mechanisms and productivity enhancement measures

% of population covered by weather index-based insurance mechanism
Improved damage rate in rice farming

comment.narrative:
No families are currently covered by WIBI in the project target sites
Average damage rate from 30-year history for rice is 22-26% but the damage rate from target population will be established during the inception phase of the project.

At least 3,000 families in target villages are covered by WIBI
Beneficiary farmers demonstrate 20% damage rate (i.e. 2-6% lower than average) during the normal year (i.e. when WIBI pay-outs are not made)

For the first batch of beneficiaries covering the June 2015 rice cropping season, project will be providing WIBI to 251 farmers by 30 June 2015 or 12.55% of the total.
For this initial reporting period, indicator on reduced damage rate in rice farming cannot be measured at this time.

description.narrative: Regulatory and fiscal incentive structures adjusted to stimulate private sector engagement in climate risk reduction and transfer for agriculture-based rural households.

Availability of an incentive mechanism for private sector in WIBI provision
PCIC’s readiness in expanding WIBI to new crops beyond rice and corn

comment.narrative:
Currently there is no incentive mechanism in place to stimulate private sector engagement in WIBI provision
PCIC is not ready for designing a new WIBI contract beyond rice and corn

The application of AGFP adjusted/expanded for FSPs to avail preferential guarantee coverage
Preliminary assessments for covering new crops under WIBI are complete and PCIC is ready to start pilot testing

Board approval of amended Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Agricultural Guarantee Fund Pool (AGFP) has been obtained in April 2015; in the process of endorsement to the Secretary of the Department of Agriculture for final approval. AGFP Special Orders for accredited FSPs to avail of preferential guarantee coverage have been drafted. The Project will support the Agricultural Credit Policy Council and the AGFP to help raise awareness of their partner FSPs on the preferential guarantee coverage availment and benefits.
Preliminary discussions among relevant agencies on expanding WIBI to new crops beyond rice have been initiated - corn and other high value crops such as coconut with available rainfall correlation studies will be further studied for further refinement and demonstration.

comment.narrative: No families are currently covered by WIBI in the project target sites
At least 3,000 families in target villages are covered by WIBI [The number of female-headed households as well as gender disaggregated performance, where possible, will be reported]
For the first batch of beneficiaries covering the June 2015 rice cropping season, project will be providing WIBI to 251 farmers by 30 June 2015 or 12.55% of the total target.

description.narrative: Farmers and producers organizations able to analyze climate risk, and develop and implement adaptation practices to enhance productivity in agriculture

comment.narrative: There has not been barangay-level vulnerability assessments to date

At least 30 barangays are aware of both slow and sudden climate risks and of response measures
At least 600 farmers and 20 farmers associations have been trained on resilient agriculture techniques [Gender-disaggregated target will be determined during the inception phase of the project]

The first batch of 251 farmers from 49 barangays in Regions X and XI received training on climate change basics and good agricultural practices from concerned government agencies, as part of their enrollment into the WIBI program.
